caption: Not the most popular museum in France (let alone in Paris), but a visit is highly recommended for those who loved history, anthropology, evolution and most of all- the best view on the famous Eiffel Tower! The design of the museum is unique and suitable for kids and families.  We spent about 2 hours in the museum and we recommended at least that for a good experience, if you are short on time, skip some of the regular collection and go to the temporary exposition instead. Those are changing frequently and can be better sometimes. We visited during the exposition on immigration and it was absolutely incredible and eye opening.

It's a nice museum next to Trocad√©ro. It tells about the history of men and where we are heading. Also one of the best places to view the Eiffel tower. You can visit this museum for free if you have the CAF or for a reduced fee if you're a student. You can also see some great preserved animals in there which will definitely amaze you. It's just next to the Eiffel Tower and also it has Welcome written in over 100 languages. The museum also shows a few cultures and fossils of humans from the pre historic era. It also shows the Neanderthal skulls if you're into history of humans and evolution üß¨

It is a nice museum; however, i would recommend going there if you have kids. It's a fun interactive museum for kids to learn about evolution and the history of humanity but as a grown person it was not extremely interesting for me albeit it was a great experience nonetheless.
Interesting museum, especially for people who like anthropology!
The Mus√©e de la Marine is definitly worth a visit. The current exposition on the Vend√©e Globe a must see

My kids‚Äô favourite museum in Paris. Very interesting display of human anatomy, different homo species, brains of various animals, and some fun interactive exhibits of human language. Beautiful view of Eiffel Tower too. Only complaint was that the cafe was very slow, only one girl there to heat up pizza, take orders, and clean the tables. Queued for a good twenty minutes during lunch time on a busy weekend.

I enjoyed the temporary exhibition about Lespugue (though thought there could have been more women artists). There were some interesting articles in the permanent exhibition but I personally didn‚Äôt love the layout, it felt all chucked in to a big space. There is a great view of the Eiffel Tower from the cafe. I was there on nuit des mus√©es and there was a dance performance where all the (white) dancers were painted black and this made me very uncomfortable (would be a 3 star if not for this).
I visited the Migration exhibition. It was nicely organised place.

Barely anything was in English and it costs 15 euros. This museum is about ‚ÄúMan‚Äù which you probably have the same information as the museum of science back in the states and that‚Äôs normally free.

The entry fee is 15‚Ç¨ however the museum is very small and there's barely anything to see. The museum claims to have one of the largest collections of prehistoric fossils but there are only very few, completely unidentifiable and very small bone fragments. Basically none of the explanatory texts were translated into English and the museum staff does not care that kids are literally screaming and running around the museum, which given the acoustics, can be heard on all 2 levels of the museum. If you are an adult who's interested in prehistory, this "museum" must be averted at all costs. If you're a parent looking for a place to let your kid run free, this is the place for you to come.

As far as I know, it was closed for 6 years for renovation works, with President Fran√ßois Hollande reopening it in 2015. I am therefore glad that I had the chance to visit it after the new adaptations.  It is a permanent exhibition, therefore those who plan to visit it either this year or in 5 years, will not miss anything.  The exhibition follows three parts, based on three essential questions: 'Who are we?', 'Where do we come from?'  and 'Where are we heading?'.  I liked the intention of the general scientific commissioner of the Gallery of Man ‚Äî to create a path, a history, for the visitor to travel.  And that's really what happens: from the human body it makes a leap to a few million years before our era.  And the road ends with a car from the 60s from Dakar, recovered from Senegal.  The one you will probably find animated on the entrance ticket, if they don't change this appearance in the meantime. From the point of view of the historian, the ethnography and anthropology museum and library is supported by the state. The entrance is free for students and pupils, while for adults the ticket price starts from 5‚Ç¨.

What a lovely museum and surprise to delight the eyes and encourage your curiosity about our origins! We came inside to get out out of the freezing wet cold and this exhibit did not disappoint and we were all very pleasantly surprised! We also had a lovely view of the Eiffel Tower and a great photo opportunity.  There was even a temporary exhibit which included highlights on HipHop Culture (called Sneakers) ... you know this Brooklyn girl was loving that!!

Following an enchanting tour of the Eiffel Tower, a visit to the Mus√©e de l'Homme (Museum of Man) seemed like an ideal way to continue exploring the rich cultural landscape of Paris. While the museum offers a fascinating insight into human history and anthropology, certain aspects made the experience slightly less enjoyable.  The museum's exhibits are undeniably intriguing, showcasing various aspects of human evolution, culture, and society. However, one challenge that detracted from the overall experience was the limited availability of English translations for the displays. In contrast to other museums in Paris, which generally provide content in both French and English, the Mus√©e de l'Homme seemed to cater primarily to French-speaking visitors.  This language barrier made it difficult to fully appreciate the depth and significance of the exhibits, leaving non-French speaking guests feeling somewhat excluded from the learning experience. While the visual elements of the displays were still engaging, the lack of accessible information prevented a deeper understanding of the subject matter.  In conclusion, the Mus√©e de l'Homme offers a captivating glimpse into human history and culture, making it a worthwhile stop on a Parisian itinerary. However, the limited availability of English translations may pose a challenge for some visitors. Despite this drawback, the museum still provides an interesting and educational experience for those who are able to navigate the language barrier.

An amazing place that shows different aspects of human civilization from our languages, the food, views of death, the rise of urbanization, etc. Highly recommend coming if you find yourself in Paris.  Entrance is also free for students which is amazing.

A very nice museum that was renewed and enlarged between 2005 and 2015. It displays in addition to its permanent exposition several temporary ones each year. The one that I visited today was as shown in my pictures: Picasso and the prehistory that is dedicated to the effects of the prehistoric discoveries on Picasso works.
Currently an exhibition dedicated to spitting at the world! I recommend it
Interesting to visit to know more about humanbeing and humanity evolution Has great view on Eiffel tour

What an exciting place. First it has a stunningly view on the gardens and the Eiffel Tower. Including from the cafeteria. Then very thought-provoking collections in airy spaces with very confortable sofas if you decide you need a rest. Very recommended.

Want to experience a unique view of the tour Eiffel? get yourself a ticket to the Galerie de l'Homme. You can learn a lot about quite a few different cultures from around the world in this ethnographic museum, it is interactive and definitely worth visit. Do not miss the part dedicated to languages on the verge of extinction: do not be squeamish, pull the tongues that stick out of the wall and listen to languages and only a handful of people know. At the time of my visit was also present a stunning photographic exhibition by Lekha Singh "Women Carry the World"  Oh about the tower, go on the 2nd floor, grab one of the sandwiches to the museum cafe (one of the cheapest in Paris, yet delicious!) sit down and enjoy the view.
This was the home base for NBC and the Today Show during the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris.
My 8yr old daughter really enjoyed herself here. We stayed about 2 hours on our way to the Eiffel Tower.
We were pleasantly surprised by this museum, no lines and free admission for under 26 years old, not very busy with tourists but also not all the descriptions were in both French and English.
Located at the center of Paris, the Home Museum is clean, clear and large space. It's a very good ambiance for the arts expo.
Great museum with a cool temporary exhibition on at the moment
Fascinating anthropology museum. One of my favorite museums in Paris! It also has a good view of the Tour Eiffel.
It's THE view at Eiffel Tower. Better be there at the earliest hours to avoid masses of tourists.
Smaller than expected, but still very interactive and interesting walk through human civilization's start to how we've evolved and continue evolving. Great for kids and non-French speakers too!

A bit small compared to other museums but very interesting. Recommended if you don't have much time to visit Paris. *Photo taken from the museum, the view of the Eiffel Tower is beautiful and not many people know about this.

I unfortunately didn't have time wonder around this museum, but I did have a meal on the terrace at restaurant as we had an unusually warm October evening. I can honestly say it was a beautiful evening enhanced by the views of The Eiffel Tower all lit up with lights, the amazing tasting menu, the ambiance and service was very good. I would highly recommend this place to eat.
Went to see Wax. It did not disappoint.
Lots of information & activities for children to enjoy ü™ÜüééüåèBattalion suggestion: improve security system so visitors don‚Äôt have to show tickets several times
I have bowel cancer and a stoma and was rudely refused entry to use a disabled toilet. I had used Google translate to explain.
Great view and well put together‚Ä¶ however hardly any English translations to be seen anywhere. Made for a disappointing experience
Absolutely NOTHING is written in English. Very disappointing. I had to make a complain about it only to find out there was an app that nobody told me about at the beginning
Great museum! Very underrated, with good exhibitions about humanity and culture. It's kept in mint condition and the cafeteria has a great view of the Eiffel Tower.

Everything and anything you want to know about the human race, it's cultural diversity, it's adaptability, it has everything from crop development to artificial limbs. while we were there they had a special exhibit on the neanderthal. It is a massive place and I don't think you can do it in one day but it's definitely worth the visit.

This is a great museum. There are a lot of interactive features located in the museum. It is nice and clean and the staff is very friendly. The restaurant inside the museum is great as well. Overall it is a fairly priced museum with lots of exhibits.
Tr√®s gentil One of my fave museum üíñüå† I like to visite at evening from Ternes
